ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I developed a better understanding of all the ethical questions that must be considered in research, specifically related to funding and plagiarism.
Knowledge of issues that plague scientific publications, including data falsification and fabrication, plagiarism, AI-generated text, and biases in the peer-review process
Research skills, how to guide my own research, and then more ethical components surrounding research (PI relations, dealing with data, communicating effectively, issues in modern research culture)

I work at the Bartholomew Lab on reverse diels alder of anthracene derivatives for use as ligands in MOFs. Extra lectures educated me on scientific ethics and history of science. The lectures were engaging and interactive which made class time fly by.
Research and collaborating with other students.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Good course and you learn some fun stuff in the ethics component

Strengths: low workload, interesting topics. Weaknesses: the in-class discussions are not engaging at all. Dr. Parr, although a lovely person, does not facilitate meaningful discussions, and often I leave class wondering what I should've taken away. Next semester, I hope that topics are explored more in-depth and student ideas discussed more thoroughly, rather than Dr. Parr replying with devil's advocate quips that pivot somewhere else.
Overall a good introduction to ethics and conduct in scientific research, course could improve by incorporating more feedback from students into the curriculum
Incredibly interesting but highly dependent on the professor you work with, which all undergraduate students should keep in mind. The weekly class was also interesting.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Needed for BS major and its a structured way to do research. Though the structure of your research depends heavily on your PI
Yesssss, find a lab that youre interested in though.
Absolutely. Even if you do not need to take the course, I would highly recommend it.
